This post I'm just going to recite my thoughts. I'm sure this will nausiate most in here, but there might be someone out there interested. 
 
 There is another explanation for life, beside the materialistic, scientific explanation. As a Creationist I realize materialists have taken every ounce of common sense, every logical idea and twisted it into something highly illogical, highly unbelievable and propped it up as "fact" under the cloak of "science." In this post I'm going to try and reverse some of the damage they've done and restore some order and common sense.
 
 --------------------------------------------------
 
 When you sit back and look at this whole thing, the debate is so polar opposite it's almost eery. But I just thought I'd compare and contrast what I consider the most obvious difference in philosophy.
 
 Materialists: believe that lifeforms are evolving upwards from something ugly (bacteria, fungues, etc) by way of a purely physical mechanism...(no thought or intelligence required)
 
 SS: believes that we are devolving downwards from something beautiful (God) by way of the mind or mental processes.
 
 Materiatists: say genes get passed down through the generations.
 
 SS: says the mind gets passed down through the generations.
 
 Materialists: say the genes control the mind
 
 SS: says the mind controls the genes
 
 With this comparison, it is easy to see who the real competitors are: the competition is between the physical actions of genes and the mental/spiritual processes of the mind. It can be no other way. Either information gets squeezed out of the random actions of genes or it gets squeezed out of the purposeful processes of the mind. 
 
 Evolutionists give the genome the credit for being the origin of information. I, on the otherhand acknowledge that the genome is a data base of information, but it's merely a storage device and does not act as a generator of information. I agree with Pierre Grasse's statement:
 
 "But according to Darwinian doctrine and Crick's central dogma, DNA is not only the depository and distributor of the information but its SOLE CREATOR. I do not believe this to be true." Pierre Grasse 
 
 
 And since physical, mechanical, random, unintelligent processes cannot account for information's source, then the only logical alternative is a non-physical, non-mechanical, non-random, intelligent reality -- ultimately God. But as creation is a spiritual reflection of God, all creatures are ultimatley designed reflecting God's spiritual qualities, starting with consciousnes, awareness, and ultimately information. Thus, information's source resides in our minds just as it resides in God's mind. Obviously different creatures were designed with different qualities, abilities and information.
 
 But ever since the fall, the mind (and information) has been degenerating and losing complexity. We've recently learned from J.C. Sanford that the genome is most definitely degenerating. See here, if not familiar with Dr. Sanford.
 
 http://www.amazon.com/Genetic-Entropy-Mystery-Genome-Sanford/dp/1599190028/ref=pd_bbs_sr_1/104-2036682-8463154?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1190337930&sr=1-1
 
 We see proof of degeneration all around us with all the new crop of genetic diseases popping up. Society is certainly degenerating genetically...this fact alone dispells the notion that we're in the process of increasing in complexity, as darwinists insist...instead we're deteriorating, decreasing in complexity. But is the genome itself the source of degeneration? I would say not because I believe the mind and mental processes are in control of the genome...and if this is the case, then the spiritual MIND is ultimately what's degenerating, which makes the physical genome, which is just a physical manifestation of the mind, a follower of degeneration, not a leader. Likewise, with the emergence of new traits, the genome (the storage device) is not the leader, it's the follower. New traits don't come from a change in the genome, new traits come from a change in the mind. 
 
 How is this possible? How is it possible that a change in the mind would result in a change of physical traits? Atheists like to envision a strawman version of God as being some sort of mysterious old man in the sky who occasionally drops in on us earthlings. Reality, however, is that we are living in HIS world -- His universe -- HIS creation. You've probably heard the song "He's got the whole world in His hands." It might sound cheesy to some, but I think there's a great deal of truth in those lyrics. We are living in His reality, in His hands. Therefore, what seems impossible (mental processes quickly creating new, heritable physical traits) is entirely possible, entirely real, and entirely unexplainable -- as is life itself. 
 
 And all this makes sense from a Biblical perspective. Remember how it was that Adam and Eve walked and talked in the Garden with God?..they evidently had daily conversations with him. But for Adam and Eve to be in God's presence they must have been a perfect spiritual creation....(God cannot be in the presense of imperfection.) So I believe Adam and Eve were probably created perfectly and designed to live forever....But then, sin entered world and everything changed. But it wasn't God who changed, man did. Sin separated man not only mentally/spiritually from God, but physically as well. 
 
 This degeneration continues today and is getting worse. Not only is spiritual degeneration worsening, but so is physical degeneration....they're both tied together in an inexplicably inseparable way....and they've got nowhere else to go but down.

Reverse transcriptase
 From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
 
 Reverse Transcriptase
 
 3D model of HIV reverse transcriptase
 Other names: Deoxynucleoside-triphosphate:
 DNA deoxynucleotidyltransferase (RNA-directed)
 
 * RNA-directed DNA polymerase
 * DNA nucleotidyltransferase (RNA-directed)
 * Revertase
 
 Database Links
 EC number: 2.7.7.49
 
 In biochemistry, a reverse transcriptase, also known as RNA-dependent DNA polymerase, is a DNA polymerase enzyme that transcribes single-stranded RNA into single-stranded DNA. Normal transcription involves the synthesis of RNA from DNA, hence reverse transcription is the reverse of this.
 
 Reverse transcriptase was discovered by Howard Temin at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, and independently by David Baltimore in 1970. The two shared the 1975 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine with Renato Dulbecco for their discovery.
 
 Commonly used examples of reverse transcriptases include:
 
 * HIV-1 reverse transcriptase from the human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (PDB 1HMV)
 * M-MLV reverse transcriptase from the Moloney murine leukemia virus
 * AMV reverse transcriptase from the avian myeloblastosis virus
 * Telomerase reverse transcriptase that maintains the telomeres of eukaryotic chromosomes
 
 
 
 [edit] Viruses
 
 The enzyme is encoded and used by reverse-transcribing viruses, which use the enzyme during the process of replication. Reverse-transcribing RNA viruses, such as retroviruses, use the enzyme to reverse-transcribe their RNA genomes into DNA, which is then integrated into the host genome and replicated along with it. Reverse-transcribing DNA viruses, such as the hepadnaviruses, transcribe their genomes into an RNA intermediate and then, using reverse transcriptase, back into DNA.
 
 [edit] Eukaryotes
 
 Self-replicating stretches of eukaryotic genomes known as retrotransposons utilise reverse transcriptase to move from one position in the genome to another via a RNA intermediate. They are found abundantly in the genomes of plants and animals. Telomerase is another reverse transcriptase found in many eukaryotes, including humans, which carries its own RNA template; this RNA is used as a template for DNA replication[1].
 
 [edit] Prokaryotes
 
 Reverse transcriptases are also found in bacterial retrons, distinct sequences which code for reverse transcriptase, and are used in the synthesis of msDNA.
 
 [edit] Structure
 
 Reverse transcriptase enzymes include an RNA-dependent DNA polymerase and a DNA-dependent DNA polymerase, which work together to perform transcription. In addition to the transcription function, retroviral reverse transcriptases have a domain belonging to the RNase H family which is vital to their replication.
 
 [edit] Replication fidelity
 
 Reverse transcriptase has a high error rate when transcribing RNA into DNA as unlike DNA polymerases it has no proofreading ability. This high error rate allows mutations to accumulate at an accelerated rate relative to proofread forms of replication. The commercially available reverse transcriptases produced by Promega are quoted by their manuals as having error rates in the range of 1 in 17,000 bases for AMV and 1 in 30,000 bases for M-MLV[2]

 While you search for the data you need. Consider this brief excerpt from WIKI:
 
 
Chromatophore
 From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
  Learn more about using Wikipedia for research 
 Jump to: navigation, search
 Zebrafish chromatophores mediate background adaptation on exposure to dark (top) and light environments (bottom).
 Zebrafish chromatophores mediate background adaptation on exposure to dark (top) and light environments (bottom).
 
 Chromatophores are pigment-containing and light-reflecting cells found in amphibians, fish, reptiles, crustaceans, and cephalopods. They are largely responsible for generating skin and eye colour in cold-blooded animals and are generated in the neural crest during embryonic development. Mature chromatophores are grouped into subclasses based on their colour (more properly "hue") under white light: xanthophores (yellow), erythrophores (red), iridophores (reflective / iridescent), leucophores (white), melanophores (black/brown) and cyanophores (blue). The term can also refer to coloured, membrane associated vesicles found in some forms of photosynthetic bacteria.
 
 Some species can rapidly change colour through mechanisms that translocate pigment and reorient reflective plates within chromatophores. This process, often used as a type of camouflage, is called physiological colour change. Cephalopods such as octopus have complex chromatophore organs controlled by muscles to achieve this, while vertebrates such as chameleons generate a similar effect by cell signaling. Such signals can be hormones or neurotransmitters and may be initiated by changes in mood, temperature, stress or visible changes in local environment.

Granted, the information may be coded or saved in the genes for future generations, but as far as being a cause for change, genes have nothing to do with it. Ultimately, the signal for change must arise from somewhere else....and I would say whatever it is that makes the organism alive is where this signal originates. Since you refuse to believe there's a difference between a living and non-living thing, then that would explain why you have problems envisioning where the signal originates -- because you don't believe such a "signal-sender" exists. But I do...and this signal-sender surely works in the sub-conscious background and in the conscious foreground as well.
chemist99a

I said in my OP I believe the genes are just a physical manifestation of the mind. They are all a part of the circle of life....of course you couldn't have one without the other.

 
 Its transparently obvious that genes can exist without a brain or a mind. Plants for example most certainly do have genes, but brains no, minds no. Or should you wish to claim otherwise then bash away. Prove plants have brains and minds. Feel free. Or don't you know jack about biology.
chemist99a

genes, I would suggest, have little or nothing to nothing to do with the cause of a color change in a fish...or for that matter any other new trait. Granted, the information may be coded or saved in the genes for future generations, but as far as being a cause for change, genes have nothing to do with it. Ultimately, the signal for change must arise from somewhere else....and I would say whatever it is that makes the organism alive is where this signal originates. l.
 
 
 Genes are of course intimately involved. They defined the structure and function of the fish in the first place. All the molecular devices in the control loop are specificed by genes either directly or otherwise. Right down to the synthetic pathways for the neurohormones and the specific protein receptor molecules which respond to them - and of course much of the pigments. Having fun yet? And by the way - the signal which triggers the color change is the environment - at least thats whats sensed and subsequently generates a causal cascade of signals and effectors.
 
 As to the "signal sender" its just biochemistry in action. Again I strongly suggest you take a look at STKE on the Science site.

 Will give you a taste of signals passed around between cells in organisms. Links give more and you can find a large volume of material on the web.

Slightly edited quote:
 
 
SS: We are devolving [downwards] from something beautiful (God).
 
 SS: says the mind gets passed down through the generations.
 
 SS: says the mind controls the genes

 
 Now that hardly constitutes a philosophy now does it. And of the three components which do you have any evidence for? And one has to ask if the mind is devolving with the rest of us and if so is it at risk of being unable to control the genes for much longer? As the mind devolves will not the rate of devolution rapidly increase and we will eventually fade away to ugly nothingness! Poof end of life.
Peeling

Materialists: believe that lifeforms are evolving upwards from something ugly (bacteria, fungues, etc) by way of a purely physical mechanism...(no thought or intelligence required)

 
 Not true, as I've pointed out to you several times now. The volitional input of creatures absolutely does indirectly steer the course of their evolution.
 
 
SS: believes that we are devolving downwards from something beautiful (God) by way of the mind or mental processes.

 
 That's both empirically wrong (oldest fossils are of much simpler organisms than exist today) and dreadfully depressing.
 
 
Materiatists: say genes get passed down through the generations.

 
 And since this is inarguable, empirical fact, we're fairly safe in saying so :)
 
 
Materialists: say the genes control the mind

 
 Um, no, they don't. Genes can regulate the production of chemicals (empirical facty), chemicals can influence your mood (empirical fact) and your mood can influence your decisions (empirical fact). That's not the same as 'controlling the mind', that's just your physiology giving you hints whose usefulness has been empirically established over many generations. The fight-or-flight reflex, for instance.
 
 
SS: says the mind controls the genes

 
 ...and provides no evidence in support of this assertion.
 
 
And since physical, mechanical, random, unintelligent processes cannot account for information's source,

 
 Perhaps if you could make some headway towards defining 'information' we could see if that were true or not.
 
 
But ever since the fall, the mind (and information) has been degenerating and losing complexity. We've recently learned from J.C. Sanford that the genome is most definitely degenerating. See here, if not familiar with Dr. Sanford.

 
 EDIT: Sorry about that, confused two publications. I'll look into what Sanford has to say.
 
 
We see proof of degeneration all around us with all the new crop of genetic diseases popping up.

 
 With 6,000,000,000 or so of us around, the odds of such events happening to someone, somewhere, are much greater than they ever used to be. Plus, our ability to even diagnose such illnesses is relatively recent - how do you know they're 'new'?
 
 
New traits don't come from a change in the genome, new traits come from a change in the mind. 

 
 Tell that to a genetically spliced organism.
 
 
Therefore, what seems impossible (mental processes quickly creating new, heritable physical traits) is entirely possible, entirely real, and entirely unexplainable -- as is life itself. 

 
 Certainly, if you invoke an all-powerful god, anything is possible. You can literally believe anything you like. That doesn't make you right, though. In fact, since the number of possible 'truths' opened up by the introduction of an omnipotent creator is essentially infinite, the odds of you picking the right one purely on faith are practically non-existent.
 
 By all means, choose to believe whatever you like. You can sit at home believing that the mind guides evolution, and that we're all inevitably devolving from perfection, and meanwhile scientists can get on with studying reality, making discoveries, finding cures for things - you know, the stuff they do - and at the end of the day we can compare whose 'philosophy' made the greatest contribution to humanity.
Peeling

Ok, regarding Sandford's work:
 
 The first thing to point out is that numerous recent examples of selection driving beneficial alleles towards local fixation have been found in the human genome, which rather undermines Sanford's claim that it can't happen.
 
 The linked document is rather heavy-going for the layperson, but it clearly shows, for example, the adaptive diversion of european and african phenotypes (melanism), the 6-10,000 year old strong selection of genes that aid the metabolism of carbohydrates (which tallies quite nicely with other evidence indicating the time we begain farming), genes that (if I'm reading this right) aid in the metabolism of alcohols, since they were invented...
 
 Even if you insist the mind is taking the lead, we're not seeing corruption and devolution, we're seeing adaptation.

 Yes it is an assertion, but it is also an assertion when evolutionists claim that genes control the epigenome whenever epigenetics is brought up. This is just an assertion with absolutely no validity. I could then come right back and say that the mind controls the genome which codes the epigenome. It's all anyone's guess. Therefore, it's hard to believe that the genes code anything when they don't even code the operations of their own cell. Something else is in control....and this something is everywhere in the body at once.

supersport

Dr. Bruce Lipton from "The Biology of Belief"
 
 "Following enucleation, many cells can survive for up to two or more months without genes. Viable enucleated cells do not lie about like brain-dead lumps of cytoplasm on life-support systems. These cells actively ingest and metabolize food, maintain coordinated operation of their physiologic systems (respiration, digestion, excretion. motility, etc) retain an ability to communicate with other cells, and are able to engage in appropriate response to growth and protection-requiring environmental stimuli."  pg 65-66
 
 http://www.brucelipton.com/
 
 "The new biology revealed that the brain of the cell is its skin, the mem-brane, the interface of the interior of the cell and the ever-changing world we live in. It is the functional element that controls life. This is important because understanding its function reveals that we are not victims of our genes. Through the action of the cell membrane we can actually control our genes, our biology and our life and we have been doing it all along although we have been laboring under the belief that we are victims.
 
 I started to realize that the cell was a chip and that the nucleus was a hard disk with programs. The genes were programs. As I was typing this on my computer one day I realized that my computer was like a cell. It had programs built into it but what was expressed by the computer was not determined by the programs. It was determined by the information that I, as the environment, was typing onto the keyboard. Suddenly all the pieces fell into place: the cell membrane is actually an information-processing computer chip. The cell's genes are the hard drive with all the potentials. That is why every cell in your body can form any kind of cell because every nucleus has all the genes that make up a human. But why should one cell be skin and another cell be bone or eye?
 
 The answer is not because of the gene programs but because of the feedback of information from the environment. All of a sudden the bigger thing hit me: what makes us different from each other is the presence of a set of unique identifying protein keys (receptors) comprising the keyboard on the surface of our cells. The identity keys on the cell membrane respond to environmental information. The biggest "Aha!" was this: that our identity is actually an environmental signal that is playing through the keyboard on the surface of our cells and engaging our genetic programs; you are not inside your cell, you are playing through your cell using the keyboard as an interface. You are an identity derived from the environment."

The Wisdom of Your Cells Part 2: How Your Beliefs Control Your Biology
 
 Conventional physics sees the human body as a machine made of atoms and molecules but the quantum physicists reveal that underneath that apparent physical structure there is nothing other than energy. That means we are energy beings interacting with everything in the entire energy field. What we are beginning to recognize is that there is an invisible world that we have not dealt with in regard to understanding the nature of our health. In other words, rather than focusing on matter, in a quantum world we focus on energy. In the world we live in we are entangled in an unfathomable number of energy vibrations and we are connected to all of them! In trying to understand a person's health, if you only focus on the physical, you miss the energy. If you only focus on the person, you miss the influence of the field. We are coming into a more holistic way of studying the fact that everything is one whole.

cience 21 September 2007:
 Vol. 317. no. 5845, p. 1687
 DOI: 10.1126/science.1147475
 
 Prev | Table of Contents | Next
 Policy Forum
 MEDICINE:
 The Future of Personal Genomics
 Amy L. McGuire,1* Mildred K. Cho,2 Sean E. McGuire,3 Timothy Caulfield4
 
 On 31 May 2007, James Watson was handed a miniature hard drive containing his personal genome sequence, which was subsequently uploaded onto publicly accessible databases. Craig Venter's personal genome was published a few months later (1). These projects represent research milestones. They also present an opportunity to examine the ethical, social, and clinical implications of personal genomics.
 
 Excitement over these projects has been tremendous. Many are willing to pay a hefty price to be next. Scientists predict that within 5 years DNA sequencing technologies will be affordable enough that personal genomics will be integrated into routine clinical care (2). Companies are responding by offering their services for ancestry tracing, forensics, nutritional advice, reproductive assistance, and even social networking. It will not be long before companies are able to offer a "Facebook-like service centered around our genomes" (3). The medical community needs to consider the ways in which routine generation of this information will affect our health system and how this information might be used outside the medical context.
 
 Despite limited treatment options for many genetic conditions, genetic testing has revolutionized the clinical management of patients for many disorders. Building on this history, companies and genetic testing laboratories have begun to develop technologies for genetic testing on a broader scale. For example, Baylor College of Medicine offers microarray analyses to evaluate a fetus for over 65 disorders or for genomic errors associated with autism or mental retardation (4).
